title: How to Understand Energy Bills

steps.headline: Find the account summary.
steps.description: The account summary will have the most important information found on your bill. It will include how much you’ve paid year to date, your current charges, and the date that your bill is due. The account summary can usually be found on the first page of your bill. The account summary is usually labeled.

steps.headline: Look at the past due amount.
steps.description: The past due amount is the current balance on your account. If this number is 0, it means that you are paid up to date and you just need to pay your most current bill. If you have accrued a balance on your account from missing payments, you’ll see the amount of money that you owe for past bills.

steps.headline: Read the current amount due.
steps.description: The current amount due is the charge on your current bill combined with the past due amount. This represents the total charge that you need to pay the energy company to bring your account to current.

steps.headline: Find the contact and payment details on the bill.
steps.description: If you need to contact your electric company to ask questions about your bill, their contact information should be found on the first page. This page will also provide details on how you can pay your bill and will include the address or phone number you can use to make payments. Remember to include the front page of your bill if you're paying through the mail so they can apply the payment to your account. Many companies have an online payment system. You can usually find this URL on the front page of the bill.

steps.headline: Determine what your base charge is.
steps.description: Companies will sometimes charge a flat fee regardless of how much energy you use. This is known as the base fee and will be the same every month.

steps.headline: Understand how your energy usage is measured.
steps.description: kWh stands for kilowatt hour and is used to measure your energy consumption. Each kilowatt-hour is the equivalent to 1,000 watt-hours. In other words, if you used a 1,000-watt appliance for an hour you'd be billed for 1 kWh. The more kWh you use, the higher your bill will be. You can reduce the amount of kWh you use by turning off lights, appliances, and electronic equipment when you aren’t using it.

steps.headline: Locate your supply or generation charge.
steps.description: The amount of kWh you use per month is multiplied by your supply or generation charge which can be found in the "rate" column on most bills. This is the amount that the energy company charges you per kWh and can vary depending on your supplier. Typically this charge is a couple of cents or a fraction of a cent. For example, if your supply charge was .5 USD and you used 100 kWh, you’d owe $50 in supply or generation charges.

steps.headline: Evaluate the distribution or delivery charge.
steps.description: Your supply or generation charge only covers the energy supplier's portion of the bill. Distribution or delivery charges are the cost of maintaining the infrastructure that delivers the energy to your home.

steps.headline: Understand what’s included in additional charges.
steps.description: The additional charges on your account can pay for meter maintenance, taxes, or local efforts for environmental conservation. These charges will depend on the environmental initiatives and tax rate near you.

steps.headline: Evaluate the energy usage graph and table if you have one.
steps.description: The energy usage graph and table shows your yearly usage of energy by month and your average usage every day. You may notice spikes during certain times of year, such as months where you run your air conditioning.

steps.headline: Understand whether you’re paying a viable or fixed rate.
steps.description: A fixed rate plan will charge you a fixed rate for each kWh you use throughout the duration of the contract. This can make it easier to predict how much you’ll have to pay for your usage but can make your bill more expensive if the price of energy price drops throughout the year. A variable rate changes based on the level of usage throughout the year and energy price increases and decreases. Energy contracts typically last 6 months to a year. Knowing how much energy costs throughout the year can help you get locked into a low-fixed rate.

steps.headline: Determine whether you’re billed on a tiered system.
steps.description: A tiered payment system charges you a different rate for how much kWh you use. For example, a company could charge a certain rate for energy usage up to 1,000 kWh, then increase the cost for all the energy used above that. Some companies even have multiple tiers, which is meant to encourage consumers to reduce their energy usage. If you're on a tiered system, there should be an explanation of the tiers in your bill.

steps.headline: Determine if you’re on a budget or payment plan.
steps.description: Some energy companies offer budget or payment plans that spread yearly energy costs evenly throughout the year. If you’re on a budget plan, you should have 2 billing sections on your bill. One will reflect your actual charges and the other one will reflect the amount you owe on your monthly budget plan. Budget plans prevent financial strain during seasons where energy consumption is typically higher.

steps.headline: Call your energy company if you don’t understand your plan.
steps.description: If you want to change the kind of plan you have or are unsure of certain details of your plan, call your energy company’s customer support line and talk to a representative there. They will be able to explain the different aspects of your bill and explain what kind of plan you have.
